map text: The first weather observations made in the Malayan peninsula were of temperature and wind. They were made by military officers of the English East India Company. There is no record of rainfall, probably because they were using measuring instruments they had been using on their ships to chart the weather during their voyage: ships did not carry rain gauges. They had a vested interest in studying the local weather to explore the viability of making a permenent settlement. After a settlement was established, doctors quickly took an interest in making observations. They were concerned about the 'healthiness' of the region for European colonisation and linked good weather with good health (Ward, 1830).

Interesting facts: In Singapore, the first coherent weather records we have were made under the governorship of William Farquar at Government Hill. He probably didn't make the observations himself, he was too important a figure. He likely delegated the work to a subordinate officer. In some accounts, the EEIC Bengal Native Infantry officer Charles Edward Davies was credited with making the Singapore readings.
Source:
Charles Edward Davis

Farquhar, W. (1827). Thermometrical and barometrical tables (pp. 585–586). Transactions of the Royal Asiatic Society of Great Britain and Ireland. (Call no.: RRARE 551.609595 FAR; Accession no.: B29032746K)

Malayan Meteorological Service. (1950). Annual report of the Malayan Meteorological Service, 1949 (p. 5). 

https://biblioasia.nlb.gov.sg/vol-16/issue-2/jul-sep-2020/rain#fnref:10

map text: During the 1830s, local weather observations were printed for the public in the local press but we are not sure who or why they were made. A clue from the Singapore Free Press and Mercantile Advertiser (5 March 1840) suggests that the records may have been made by an interested amateur, rather than as part of military or medical research.

Interesting facts: One such amateur was an American missionary, Joseph S. Travelli. He recorded Singapore's temperature and rainfall from the mission school where he worked, run by the American Board of Foreign Missions located at Ryan's Hill (now Bukit Pasoh).

In the 1840s, a fantastic experiment took place. Guided by the British Association for the Advancement of Science (BAAS) and the Royal Society in London, a formal observatory was established in Singapore. Run by Lieutenant Charles Elliot, an EEIC officer, it was Singapore's first semi-permanent research station to investigate magnetism, astronomy and weather.
Located along Kallang River, Elliot's observatory was described as small but well designed for making weather observations. Direct sunlight was prevented from reaching the meteorological instruments and the walls were 18 inches thick and painted white in order to reflect heat (Elliot, 1849). 
The observatory was closed in 1845 due to the withdrawal of funds from London. The instruments were sent to India for re-use in the observatory in Bombay.
Source: C. M. Elliot, Singapore Magnetic Observatory Yearbook
J. S. Travelli (1843), American Journal Arts and of Science

map text: After the observatory closed in 1845 and until the early 1860s, we don't know whether any weather observations were being made. There is no record of them but it is not clear if observations were made and lost, or there none made at all.

Interesting facts:
In the mid-1860s we start to see a weather record appear again, some made by professionals and some by semi-amateurs. Plantation owner Jonas Daniel Vaughan was the first and one of the most comprehensive observers of this period. In his early life, he had served in the Bengal Marines, before being posted to Singapore as Master Attendant and Marine Magistrate in 1856 (Gibson, 1960; Makepeace, 1921). After retirement, he started a plantation in the River Valley Road area (then known as the Killeny Estate) alongside his police duties. 
His observations (1863-6) were published in the Straits Settlements Government Gazette.

Arthur Knight, Vaughan's neighbour, also made meteorological observations at his estate at Mount Pleasant in Toa Payoh (Irvine Rowell, 1885). This would have been an incredible long series of observations spanning 17 years if all the information survived. Unfortunately, only the 1864-1869 data can be found.
Source: A. Knight, in Wheatley (1881), Journal of the Straits Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society

Interesting facts: As we can see during the 1870s, most of the weather records were made by local agriculturalists and landowners. The only official observations we know of were made at Singapore's Raffles and Horsburgh lighthouses during 1864 to 1867 by Thomas Todd (senior keeper) and J. W. Flory (second keeper) respectively (e.g. Todd, 1864). This series was short but far more detailed than those made by the amateur weather-watchers. Their bbservations included pressure, temperature, wind and rainfall and were made 3 times daily at sunrise, noon and sunset.

Horsburgh was the first lighthouse to be built through British funding in Singapore. Opened in 1850, it was named after Captain James Horsburgh, a hydrographer to the EEIC from 1810 to 1836.
The Raffles lighthouse opened four years after Horsburgh and is still in operation today. 
The lighthouse records were originally published in the Government Gazette however, they ceased to be published after 1867 although they were most likely still made. We do not know where these original records are today.

map text:
In 1869, meteorology for the Straits Settlements was brought under the control of the Medical Department for historic and practical reasons. Firstly, the interest in medical meteorology, a field of medical research that based its investigations on connections between health and weather, grew in the 19th century. As the century progressed, a quantitative method of comparing diseases incidence with meteorological data became common across the colonies of the British Empire (e.g. Walker, 1876, 1925).  Secondly, the medical department also offered a coherent infrastructure for the systematic collation of observations within a controlled environment.
The annual average from the Government Gazette is for the whole of Singapore.

Observer or Authorising Officer: H.L. Randall, Colonial Surgeon (and A.F. Anderson, Acting Pricinpal Civil Medical Officer Aug 1827 - Jun 1873)
Interesting facts:
The first official set of observations under the medical department were made in Singapore at the Convict Jail (Bras Basah) Hospital between 1869 and 1874. This hospital was originally intended to hold transported prisoners (mainly of Indian origin) from other British colonies. The weather data is very detailed and standardised, observations made 3 times a day. 
Despite the detailed records, little in known about the small-scale observatory or who made the records. The prison itself was designed and established by George Coleman, Superintendent of Public Works and of Convicts. There was an open plan area with numerous workshops and studio, one of which was presumably an observatory space (McNair & Bayliss, 1889). 
Coleman handed operations to his successor, Major John Fedrick McNair, also a prominent architect and engineer. McNair may have supervised a subordinate or even a trusted prisoner to make the observations but they were ultimately signed off by the Colonial Surgeon, H.L. Randall. 
In 1867, the practice of transporting prisoners ended and six years later, so did the observations from this hospital.
Source:
Principal Civil Medical Officer (P.C.M.O) of
the Medical Department, Government Gazette and The Straits Times
https://www.dropbox.com/sh/q6qzwclwvy30dkg/AACtvLyJn7IgIZmv5BZ3Pqr7a/Singapore%201869-1874%20Convict%20Hospital?dl=0&preview=Singapore+1869-1876+digit.xlsx&subfolder_nav_tracking=1

Wheatley, J. J. L. (1881). Notes on the rainfall of Singapore. Journal of the Straits Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society, (7), 31-50.

Interesting facts: The newly gathered long-term weather data led Principal Chief Medical Officer H.L. Randall to conclude that the amount of rainfall affected the numbers of cases of cholera, arguing that "to a great extent, the health of Singapore is dependent on its Rainfall".
Source:
A. Knight, in Wheatley (1881), Journal of the Straits Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society

http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Page/stoverland18740516-1.1.3

Interesting facts: Peninsula and Oriental Steam Navigation depot
Source:
Principal Civil Medical Officer (P.C.M.O) of
the Medical Department, Government Gazette and The Straits Times

Interesting facts: The practice of making observations at plantations also continued. Into the early 1870s for example, Alsagoff and Company, who owned lemongrass plantations in Peserverance Estate (now Geylang area), made records for rainfall that were published in the Straits Settlements Government Gazette, 1875). The family run business was headed by Syed Osmar bin Mohamed Alsagoff who was a leading member of the local Muslim community and one of the largest plantation owners in Singapore (Tan, 2009).
Source:
Principal Civil Medical Officer (P.C.M.O) of
the Medical Department, Government Gazette and The Straits Times

Principal Civil Medical Officer (P.C.M.O) of
the Medical Department, Government Gazette and The Straits Times

Principal Civil Medical Officer (P.C.M.O) of
the Medical Department, Government Gazette and The Straits Times

Observer or Authorising Officer: H.L. Randall, Principal Civil Medical Officer (up to 1876)
Interesting facts: After the Convict Jail was closed down, Kandang Kerbau Hospital took over the meteorological role, making observations in a dedicated observatory. KKH grew to become the largest medical facility in Singapore (Lee, 1990). The dataset is very detailed and standardised. Although we do not know exactly who made the observations, there were references made to the Assistant Surgeons and apothcaries working at the hospital undertaking the role (e.g. Government Gazette, 1892).
Source:
Principal Civil Medical Officer (P.C.M.O) of
the Medical Department, Government Gazette and The Straits Times

Principal Civil Medical Officer (P.C.M.O) of
the Medical Department, Government Gazette and The Straits Times

map text: Under the medical department, the number of observation stations across Singapore grew. This expansion had much to do with the enthusiasm of Principal Chief Medical Officer T. Irvine Rowell, who served as PCMO from 1877. His interest in meteorology spanned beyond the practice of medical meteorology. He studied how patterns of settlement might have impacted local weather, especially the purported connection between deforestation and rainfall, as he was interested in understanding anthropogenic changes in weather. Under him, the number of stations rose to around 29 weather stations including one at the General Hospital, Sepoy Lines and Waterworks Reservoir (MacRitchie Reservoir).

Interesting facts: MacRitchie reservoir opened at the very end of 1877 and rainfall records were made there from the following year. This dataset comprises one of Singapore's longest, as records are still kept there today. The only gap was during the second world war.
Source: MacRitchie Reservoir Monthly Rainfall, 1879 - 1948

Observer or Authorising Officer: H.L. Randall, Colonial Surgeon (and A.F. Anderson, Acting Pricinpal Civil Medical Officer Aug 1827 - Jun 1873)
Source:
Principal Civil Medical Officer (P.C.M.O) of
the Medical Department, Government Gazette and The Straits Times
A. Knight, in Wheatley (1881), Journal of the Straits Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society

Interesting facts:
In September 1903, it was suggested by R. S. Fry, who ran a small observatory with a timeball for ships on Pulau Brani, that the facility ought to be moved to Mount Faber because the accuracy of the clock were being impaired by nearby reclamation works. His advice was taken up and the observatory on Mount Faber began operation on 1 June 1905. 
In 1929, the Faber Observatory was expanded to become the first full-scale observation station in Singapore.  Singapore was also made the headquarters of the Malayan Meteorological Service with its offices located in the Fullerton Building (now hotel).
Source: Makepeace, W., Brooke, G. E., & Braddell, R. St. J. (Eds.). (1991). One hundred years of Singapore (Vol. 1). Singapore: Oxford University Press, p. 481. (Call no.: RSING 959.57 ONE-[HIS]); Ng, M. F. C. (2012). A ride to remember: The story of Mount Faber and Singapore Cable Car. Singapore: Mount Faber Leisure Group, p. 12. Available via PublicationSG.

Interesting facts: Rainfall readings at the Botanic Gardens were made at the Director's house at 8am every day from 1916-1924.
Source: https://lkcnhm.nus.edu.sg/dna/docs/0314f6d7a300fbd675f866c965f9916c.pdf

Interesting facts: Readings most likely taken at the Medical Officer's quarters.

In 1934, the Mount Faber station as well as the headquarters at the Fullerton Bulding were moved to Kallang Airport, which the authorities thought was a more suitable location for observing Singapore’s weather and for the transmission of weather information to aircraft.
Source: Survey Department. (1932). Survey Department, Straits Settlements. In Annual Departmental Reports of the Straits Settlements for the year 1931 (p. 18). Singapore: Government Printing Press. (Call no.: RRARE 325.3410959 SSADRS; Microfilm no.: NL2921)
MacRitchie Reservoir Monthly Rainfall, 1879 - 1948

Interesting facts:
The Kandang Kerbau observations were not published in the government gazettes beyong 1917 although they continued to be made. A possible explanation for their public disapperance was that the meteorology was moved out of the Medical Department and into the Museum Department under Herbert Robinson. 
After this, all meteorological returns for the peninsula were collated by specialist clerks in the employ of the Museum’s Department (SEL: SEC 1108/1925). This was the preamble to the establishment of a formal, dedicated Malayan Meteorological Department in 1929 (Maxwell & Robinson, 1927).
Yang di-Pertuan Negara Yusof Ishak peering into a weather apparatus at Paya Lebar Airport, 1961. Yusof Ishak Collection, courtesy of National Archives of Singapore.
Source: https://biblioasia.nlb.gov.sg/vol-16/issue-2/jul-sep-2020/rain#fnref:10
